results.abstract: Some of John McCain's responses to questions from The Des Moines Register came across as sarcastic.

headline.main: Sarcasm From McCain to Iowa Paper

results.snippet: Some of John McCain's responses to questions from The Des Moines Register came across as sarcastic.
results.lead_paragraph: For another candidate, it might have been characterized as a "passionate defense." But for Senator John McCain, who has long battled accusations that he has a short temper, an interview today with The Des Moines Register could be more damaging. Some of Mr. McCain's responses to questions about issues that have been prominent in the press for the past few weeks came across as sarcastic - sometimes testy. Furthermore, the Iowa newspaper put his interview with the editorial board online, leaving him vulnerable to unflattering mash-ups.

results.abstract: Republican presidential candidate John McCain's videotaped sarcastic and sometimes testy responses to The Des Moines Register's editorial board may undermine his efforts to play down accusations that he has short temper; video posted online shows McCain responding to questions about vice presidential candidate Sarah Palin's experience, health insurance and truthfulness of his campaign ads (M)
results.snippet: Senator John McCain has disputed, patiently, accusations that he has a short temper. But his sarcastic, and sometimes testy, responses to The Des Moines Register's editorial board, which the Iowa newspaper videotaped and posted online Wednesday, are...
results.lead_paragraph: Senator John McCain has disputed, patiently, accusations that he has a short temper. But his sarcastic, and sometimes testy, responses to The Des Moines Register's editorial board, which the Iowa newspaper videotaped and posted online Wednesday, are not likely to help him make that case. ''Really?'' he responded to a question about possible concern from voters about Gov. Sarah Palin's level of experience. ''I haven't detected that in the polls; I haven't detected that among the base. If there's a Georgetown cocktail party person who, quote, calls himself a conservative who doesn't like her, good luck.''

results.abstract: First article in occasional series examining five years between when NASA shuts down space shuttle program and when next generation of American spacecraft is scheduled to arrive; after program shuts down in 2010, Star City, Russia, will be only place to send astronauts from any nation to International Space Station; time lag in Bush administration's plan to retire space shuttles and work on return mission to moon thrusts program into national politics and and geopolitical controversy; presidential candidates Barack Obama and John McCain denounce gap, each promoting commitment to space program while in Florida where thousands of workers will lose their jobs when shuttle missions end; antagonism between US and Russia over conflict in Georgia is clouding future of 15-year partnership in space just when NASA will be more reliant on Russia; NASA administrator Michael D Griffin opposes dependence on Russia and is exploring idea of flying aging shuttles after 2010; China's entry into space, with space walk and plans for moon launch, further crowds debate; photos; map(M)

headline.main: One Way Up: U.S. Space Plan Relies on Russia

results.snippet: STAR CITY, Russia -- This place was once no place, a secret military base northeast of Moscow that did not show up on maps. The Soviet Union trained its astronauts here to fight on the highest battlefield of the cold war: space.     Yet these days,...
results.lead_paragraph: STAR CITY, Russia -- This place was once no place, a secret military base northeast of Moscow that did not show up on maps. The Soviet Union trained its astronauts here to fight on the highest battlefield of the cold war: space. Yet these days, Star City is the place for America's hard-won orbital partnership with Russia, where astronauts train to fly aboard Soyuz spacecraft. And in two years Star City will be the only place to send astronauts from any nation to the International Space Station.

results.abstract: Aired Thursday night on NBC: I see all the big Halloween stores opening up all across the country. Retailers say the big costume this year, pirate. All you need is a briefcase, Brooks Brothers suit, Wall Street business cards. Everybody's still talking about the presidential debate the other night. How boring it was! Experts say [...]
results.snippet: Aired Thursday night on NBC: I see all the big Halloween stores opening up all across the country. Retailers say the big costume this year, pirate. All you need is a briefcase, Brooks Brothers suit, Wall Street business cards. Everybody's still...
results.lead_paragraph: Aired Thursday night on NBC: I see all the big Halloween stores opening up all across the country. Retailers say the big costume this year, pirate. All you need is a briefcase, Brooks Brothers suit, Wall Street business cards.

headline.main: Russia Leads Way in Space Tourism With Paid Trips Into Orbit

results.snippet: The Russian space program has found ways to make space pay and has shown that it is leading the way toward the commercialization of space travel.
results.lead_paragraph: Space is for sale. While NASA looks ahead toward five years without shuttle flights and struggles to develop the next generation of spacecraft within its budget, the Russian space program has found ways to make space pay. And in doing so, the former Soviet Union has shown that it is leading the way toward capitalism in space travel.

results.abstract: Author Richard Dooling Op-Ed article contends that as current financial crisis spreads (like computer virus) on earth's nervous system (Internet), it is worth asking if we have somehow managed to outsmart ourselves using computers; maintains that Wall Street titans loved swaps and derivatives because they were unregulated by humans; says that left nobody but machines in charge; holds that physicist Freeman Dyson, science historian George Dyson and Unabomber Theordore Kaczinski warned us of this crash; drawing (M)
results.snippet: How the philosophies of a physicist, a wizard and a serial killer warned us of this financial crisis.
results.lead_paragraph: ''BEWARE of geeks bearing formulas.'' So saith Warren Buffett, the Wizard of Omaha. Words to bear in mind as we bail out banks and buy up mortgages and tweak interest rates and nothing, nothing seems to make any difference on Wall Street or Main Street. Years ago, Mr. Buffett called derivatives ''weapons of financial mass destruction'' -- an apt metaphor considering that the Manhattan Project's math and physics geeks bearing formulas brought us the original weapon of mass destruction, at Trinity in New Mexico on July 16, 1945.

results.abstract: Anthony DePalma Generations essay on changes in ways his father, his son and he chose to make living; drawing (M)

headline.main: In Finding a Way to Make a Living, Unexpected Guides

results.snippet: Plan as you may, career choices are often influenced by unexpected forces and unanticipated events.
results.lead_paragraph: I WAS only vaguely aware of what a white coat ceremony was when my wife and I attended one in New Brunswick, N.J., for our younger son, Andr√©s, who was just entering Robert Wood Johnson Medical School. How would I have known about an initiation ceremony for doctors? In the four generations that my family has been in the United States since coming from southern Italy at the turn of the last century, no one has even come close to working in medicine, unless you count a cousin who worked in the billing office of a local hospital.

results.abstract: An antidote to racy teen lit has attracted the attention of young girls and health researchers.

headline.main: Books for Girls With a Health Message

results.snippet: An antidote to racy teen lit has attracted the attention of young girls and health researchers.
results.lead_paragraph: When Addie Swartz was shopping with her 9-year-old daughter and friends, one of the girls noticed a scantily clad model at an Abercrombie & Fitch store. "Why do they have to do that?'' one of the girls asked.

results.abstract: Some American astronauts train and live in Star City, Russia, to prepare for shut down of space shuttle program in 2010; during estimated five-year-period between shutdown and implementation of new generation Constellation spacecraft, American astronauts and others traveling to International Space Station will get ride on Russian Soyuz spacecraft used since 2000; drawings; photos (L)

headline.main: For U.S. Astronauts, a Russian Second Home

results.snippet: STAR CITY, Russia -- Garrett Reisman was on his way to this formerly secret military base for several weeks of training, making his way through Kennedy Airport, when his cellphone rang. It was his boss, Steven W. Lindsey, the head of NASA's astronaut...
results.lead_paragraph: STAR CITY, Russia -- Garrett Reisman was on his way to this formerly secret military base for several weeks of training, making his way through Kennedy Airport, when his cellphone rang. It was his boss, Steven W. Lindsey, the head of NASA's astronaut office. ''Come back to Houston. They've canceled your training -- they're playing hardball,'' Mr. Reisman recalled his boss saying. He was caught in a momentarily important dispute between NASA and the Russian space agency, Roscosmos.

results.abstract: American astronaut Alan Shepard describes what happeded to two golf balls he hit during 1971 Apollo 14 mission to moon; drawing
results.snippet: Why did Alan Shepard hit a golf ball on the Moon, and what happened to it?
results.lead_paragraph: Q.What happened to the golf ball the astronaut hit on the Moon? Why did he hit it? A. Alan Shepard actually hit two balls on the Apollo 14 mission of 1971, and they are still on the Moon, he said in a 1991 interview on the Academy of Achievement Web site for students.

results.abstract: Article in series The DNA Age, which explores impact of new genetic technology on American life; public Web site personalgenomes.org will offer information about first 10 volunteers in Personal Genome Project, study at Harvard University Medical School aimed at challenging notion that secrets of genes are best kept under wraps; goal of project is to speed medical research by dispensing with elaborate precautions traditionally taken to protect privacy of human subjects; experts contend that medical research will progress faster if more information is made available; in exchange for decoding their DNA, participants agreed to make public their medical histories and variety of traits; while they cannot be denied health insurance based on genetic profile, participants may have to deal with denial of life or long-term care insurance and wrath of family members who wish to retain more privacy; photos (M)

headline.main: Project Lets Anyone Take a Peek At the Experts' Genetic Secrets

results.snippet: BOSTON -- Is Esther Dyson, the technology venture capitalist who is training to be an astronaut, genetically predisposed to a major heart attack?     Does Steven Pinker, the prominent psychologist and author, have a gene variant that raises his risk...
results.lead_paragraph: BOSTON -- Is Esther Dyson, the technology venture capitalist who is training to be an astronaut, genetically predisposed to a major heart attack? Does Steven Pinker, the prominent psychologist and author, have a gene variant that raises his risk of Alzheimer's, which his grandmother suffered from, to greater than 50 percent?

results.abstract: An appeals court panel is reviewing the exclusion of much of the police evidence against the former astronaut whose arrest after a 900-mile road trip to confront a supposed romantic rival made tabloid headlines in 2007.

headline.main: The Lisa Nowak Case, Back in Court

results.snippet: An appeals court panel is reviewing the exclusion of much of the police evidence against the former astronaut whose arrest after a 900-mile road trip to confront a supposed romantic rival made tabloid headlines in 2007.
results.lead_paragraph: By any standards, the past two years have been anything but easy for Lisa Marie Nowak.

results.abstract: Correction of Oct 14 Q&A column about what became of golf balls hit on Moon by astronaut Alan Shepard
results.snippet: An answer in the Q&A column on Oct. 14 about what became of the golf balls the astronaut Alan Shepard hit on the Moon, drawing on an interview Shepard gave in 1991, misstated the timing and details of another demonstration that showed an almost...
results.lead_paragraph: An answer in the Q&A column on Oct. 14 about what became of the golf balls the astronaut Alan Shepard hit on the Moon, drawing on an interview Shepard gave in 1991, misstated the timing and details of another demonstration that showed an almost complete absence of air resistance on the Moon. It was the astronaut David Scott, not ''other astronauts,'' who did the demonstration, and he dropped a feather and a hammer that fell at the same speed, not a feather and a lead ball. That demonstration took place during the Apollo 15 mission in July 1971, which was after -- not before -- Shepard's Apollo 14 mission, in February 1971.

results.abstract: Google is increasingly looking to energy sector as potential business opportunity; has invested millions of dollars in making its own power-hungry data centers more efficient; its philanthropic arm has made small investments in clean energy technologies; chief executive Eric E Schmidt has hinted in recent weeks at company's broad interest in energy business; joined General Electric chief executive Jeffrey R Immelt to announce they will collaborate on policies and technologies aimed at improving electricity grid; Google engineers are hoping to unveil soon tools that could help consumers make better decisions about their energy use; photos (L)

Its philanthropic arm has made small investments in clean energy technologies.

results.abstract: Reading Google on its plans for its energy initiatives: a bit like reading tea leaves.

headline.main: Google's Energy Ideas Might Emerge Under Open Source Licenses — Or Not

results.snippet: Reading Google on its plans for its energy initiatives: a bit like reading tea leaves.
results.lead_paragraph: Much of what Google is planning as it considers forays into the energy business is a tightly guarded secret. True to form, the company likes to reveal little about its future products until they are ready to be unveiled.

results.abstract: Article on Steven F Udvar-Hazy Center, National Air and Space Museum's annex in Chantilly, Va, that houses more than 150 aircraft and spacecraft; highlights of exhibits include Lockheed SR-71A Blackbird, built in 1960s, Enola Gay, replica of Wright Flyer and military's Joint Strike Fighter; photos; map (L)

headline.main: In the Temple Of the Wild Blue Yonder

results.snippet: The Steven F. Udvar-Hazy Center in Chantilly, Va., has a quieter, more worshipful feel than its companion, the Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum.

multimedia.caption: A Smithsonian Air Museum With Room to Spare
multimedia.credit: In this vast National Air and Space Museum annex, the planes and space shuttles on display seem to be plucked from the sky.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: In this vast National Air and Space Museum annex, the planes and space shuttles on display seem to be plucked from the sky.
legacy.MultimediaHeadline1: A Smithsonian Air Museum With Room to Spare

results.lead_paragraph: THE first thing visitors encounter in the main display area of the Udvar-Hazy Center, the National Air and Space Museum annex near Dulles airport in the Virginia countryside, is a huge black spy plane. It's an SR-71A Blackbird, the ultimate hot-rod aircraft, one of about 30 built at the Lockheed Skunk Works in California in the 1960s. This one last flew in 1990, traveling the 2,300 miles between Los Angeles and Washington in 1 hour 4 minutes 20 seconds -- a transcontinental blur.

results.abstract: Michael Brick Pushing The Limit column discusses former NFL linebacker Ken Harvey, who has designed game that can be played in zero-gravity; photos (M)

headline.main: Ex-N.F.L. Star Dreams of Taking Sports to Space

results.snippet: GREENBELT, Md. -- The game would be called Float Ball. It would combine elements of basketball, football and the Lionel Richie video for ''Dancing on the Ceiling'' into a sort of free-for-all, compelling weightless players to bounce off walls,...
results.lead_paragraph: GREENBELT, Md. -- The game would be called Float Ball. It would combine elements of basketball, football and the Lionel Richie video for ''Dancing on the Ceiling'' into a sort of free-for-all, compelling weightless players to bounce off walls, obstacles and one another while herding weightless balls of various colors to either end of the playing space, which would be placed inside the cabin of a zero-gravity plane or, possibly, on the moon. Eventually, one day, if all went well, some sort of custom arena would be constructed. On Mars. ''There's a bonus,'' said the game's promoter, Ken Harvey, speaking to an attentive audience of National Aeronautics and Space Administration engineers, technicians and scientists at the Goddard Space Flight Center here recently, ''where you have to pick up a person holding a certain ball and throw them through a hoop as a sort of extra point.''
